newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian Broadcasting Corp Afternoon Update.

text.p: JOBS COMMITTEE WELCOMED
The Australian Chamber of Manufactures says there's a desperate
need to stimulate economic activity and growth demands before any
turnaround in employment happens.
The latest Chamber survey has revealed a sixth consecutive
quarterly fall in employment, with a few slight signs of
improvement.
The Chamber's Alan Handberg, says without more robust activity,
there's no need for additional staff, and employers simply can't
afford to create positions.
However, both the business and manufacturing sectors have welcomed
the decision by Federal Cabinet to create a new Employment
Committee.
WATERHOUSE SUSPENSION OVERTURNED
Flamboyant trainer Gai Waterhouse can now concentrate all her
energy on this year's Spring Racing Carnival.
This follows today's ruling by the Australian Jockey Club to uphold
Mrs Waterhouse's appeal against a three month suspension.
The trainer and jockey Kevin Forrester were outed for three months
after an inquiry into the performance of Gossips in last month's
Shannon Quality.
The AJC today overturned the suspension against Mrs Waterhouse, and
reduced Forrester's suspension to two months.
Waterhouse will enter a strong contingent over the Spring Carnival,
including the short priced pre-post favourite for Saturday's Cox
Plate, Juggler.
BLACKHAWK INQUIRY HEARS MORE EVIDENCE
A Military board of inquiry into the Blackhawk collision in June
has heard a lack of flying frequency, due to maintenance problems
of one of the helicopters, contributed to the crash.
The collision between two helicopters near Townsville claimed the
lives of 18 soldiers.
Captain Scott Benbo, a co-pilot of the fifth blackhawk, told the
Inquiry he believed his aircraft was too far left of the target
during the counter-terrorism exercise.
Similar evidence has been given by the air crew of blackhawk three,
who also thought they were off track.
Captain Benbo said the lack of flying recently led to inexperienced
pilots.
He said experienced pilots were posted out, and there was a lack of
training.
POSSIBLE APPEAL OVER SWEARING POLICEMAN RULING
New South Wales Police Commissioner Peter Ryan is considering a
High Court appeal over yesterday's decision to dismiss an offensive
language charge against a swearing policeman.
The Court of Appeal upheld the controversial Police Tribunal
decision, although it heard the officer habitually used the "F"
word in the workplace.
Police Minister, Paul Whelan, has told Parliament Commissioner Ryan
is very disappointed by the ruling, and is seeking legal advice on
a High Court appeal.
Mr Whelan says if the decision goes unchallenged, it will make
police stations unacceptable work places.
ENTRIES VYING FOR SOLAR CAR HONOURS
Mexican and British entries in Sunday's World Solar Challenge are
both feeling confident about their chances of completing the nine
day race.
Entrants in the 3-thousand kilometre race will travel from Darwin
to Adelaide under the steam of solar power.
Mexican team leader Daniel Amador says his team comprises 12 people
from seven universities in Mexico City and a quarter-million-dollar
car.
Meanwhile the owner of a private British entry has one of the more
unusually built cars.
Brian Hampton says the solar panel worth eight thousand dollars is
the most expensive item on his car...the rest of the vehicle is
made from scrap.
INTERNATIONAL CUP HOPE ARRIVES
With only two weeks to the race that stops the nation, two of the
expected stars of the Melbourne Cup are due to in town tonight.
Two of the most important guests of this year's VRC Spring Racing
Carnival, Oscar Schindler and Court of Honour will arrive from the
United Kingdom to begin their mandatory quarantine period.
The VRC's Racing Manager, Les Benton, says all plans are in place
to ensure a smooth transition for both horses when they arrive at
Sandown.
KOREA TO GIVE A$200,000 TO WAR MEMORIAL
The Korean Ambassador to Australia, Byong Hyong Kwan, has announced
the South Korean Government will give 200-thousand dollars to the
Korean War Memorial in Canberra.
Mr Kwan says the money is being budgetted for in the next South
Korean budget.
He says the money was pledged by South Korean President Kim, when
he made a State visit to Australia in 1994.
HOWARD DISAPPOINTED BY UN FAILURE
Prime Minister John Howard says while he's disappointed at
Australia's failure to gain a seat on the United Nations Security
Council, it's too early to try to extrapolate the reasons.
The two, non-permanent seats went to Sweden and Portugal.
Mr Howard says it won't alter the Government's commitment to the
U-N, and is confident that the Government couldn't have done more.
CALLS FOR GOVERNMENT RETHINK ON PUBLIC SECTOR
ACTU President Jennie George says the establishment of a Cabinet
Jobs Committee signals an admission of failure by the Federal
Government.
The Prime Minister yesterday announced the new employment committee
aimed at creating jobs and improving market confidence.
Ms George says the first task of the committee should be to reverse
budget cuts to the public service.
She says it's the government's treatment of the public sector
that's driving predictions that unemployment will reach nine per
cent or more.
ATTEMPTED ESCAPEES COMMITTED TO FACE TRIAL
A 29 year old man convicted of murdering Sydney nurse Anita Cobby
and another Goulburn inmate have been committed to face trial in
the District Court for attempting to escape from custody.
John Raymond Travers was one of three prisoners facing committal
proceedings in the Goulburn Local Court charged with attempting to
escape from a prison van on June 5th this year.
It's alleged Travers, Lauteau Fatafehi, 31, and 26-year-old Steven
Allen Fuller, tried to cut through an escape hatch in a prison van
while in transit on the M5 between Goulburn and Sydney.
Magistrate Mary Jerram dismissed the charges against Fuller saying
it was possible he was simply in the same van cell and had not been
part of the escape conspiracy.
Travers and Fatafehi will face trail on a date to be fixed. - - - -
RADIO AUSTRALAI MAY LOSE TWO PROGRAMS UNDER CUTS
The general manager of Radio Australia, Derek White, says budget
cuts could force the closure of two of the station's language
services next year.
Mr White told a meeting in Melbourne of the Australian Institute of
International Affairs that the services most likely to face closure
were Cantonese, and French.
He said other important Radio Australia services -- Bahasa
Indonesian and Mandarin -- could also have to shorten the number of
hours they broadcast because of staff cut-backs.
Mr White said such moves would be necessary if Radio Australia took
a proportional share of a proposed 10 per cent cut in government
funding for the ABC.
KOREAN AMBASSADOR SEES AUSTRALIA AS OPEN SOCIETY
The Korean Ambassador to Australia, Byong Hyong Kwon, says he sees
Australia as an open liberal society where people from all over the
world live.
Mr Kwon says the concerns in Australia about increased racism will
have absolutely no impact at all on relations with South Korea,
saying it's a domestic issue.
He says he's tried to monitor the issue.
INDEPENDENT AUDITOR FOR SECOND SYDNEY AIRPORT
The Federal Government will appoint an independent environmental
auditor for the proposed second Sydney airport.
Environment minister Robert Hill says the auditor will review
documentation relied on in preparing the Environmental Impact
Statement and report on its technical adequacy.
The minister says the auditor will review the Draft E-I-S, and the
report will be publicly released.
Senator Hill says the auditor will also report on the adequacy of
the final E-I-S.
The minister has written to seven environmental consultancy firms,
asking for expressions of interest, and expects to make an
appointment within three weeks.
